data.headline: More tech innovations for philanthropy
data.description: The philanthropic sector is expanding into new ways of giving, like tech innovations (blockchain-powered donations, charity prediction markets) and new currencies (crypto, NFTs).  Some billionaire philanthropists are dedicating their fortunes to development goals, some through new philosophies like effective altruism.
data.impact_description: The impact to date is fairly small as even large philanthropic donations are dwarfed by ODA (even though some donors are cutting ODA) and new technologies/ways of giving like crypto are in their infancy (and might anyway just replace donations that would have been made through traditional means).  In the longer term, it's possible that these mechanisms, and philosophies behind giving like effective altruism, might either convince more people to give, and/or actually increase the impact of their giving (because donations are channelled to goals with greater impact).

data.headline: Climate activism expanding
data.description: In recent years, climate activism has increased with millions of people around the world taking to the streets to demand urgent action on climate change. Climate change is also increasingly becoming a focus of legal action, with individuals, organizations, and governments using the law to hold companies and governments accountable for their role in causing and exacerbating climate change.
data.impact_description: Legal action can drive change in the behaviour and practices of corporations and governments and the implementation of stronger climate policies. However, legal action is not a silver bullet, and it must be combined with broader collective action to achieve the transformative change needed to address the climate crisis.

data.headline: Increased use of weather modifying technology
data.description: There is growing interest and investment in weather modifying technology, which involves the deliberate manipulation of weather patterns to mitigate the impacts of climate change, droughts, and other weather-related hazards. These technologies range from cloud seeding and hail suppression to more complex geoengineering solutions, such as solar radiation management and carbon capture.
data.impact_description: Unilateral use of these technologies raises significant ethical, social, and environmental concerns. Weather modifying technology could have unintended consequences and risks, and may be used to further geopolitical interests or exacerbate existing inequalities.

data.headline: Boom in breakthrough technology
data.description: We are currently experiencing a boom in breakthrough technologies, with advances in fields such as green technologies, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, nanotechnology, and quantum computing.
data.impact_description: These technologies have the potential to revolutionize industries, solve some of our most pressing global challenges, and create new economic opportunities. However, they also pose significant ethical, social, and economic challenges, which require careful consideration and proactive measures to address.

data.headline: Ever-stronger AI
data.description: Advancements in AI will disrupt every industry within the next decade, and Future Today Institute classifies it as a general-purpose technology. Like the steam engine and the internet before it, AI has the potential to influence entire economies and to alter society through political, economic, and social structures.
data.impact_description: Exponential advances in digital technology are increasing the gap between the haves and the have-nots, those who aren’t shaping our digital world, or aren’t even able to participate in or benefit from it. In such a rapidly-changing field, policy and regulation for the public interest is vital, particularly in areas in which the consequences of such rapid advances are largely unknown.

data.headline: Distributed energy solutions proliferate
data.description: Distributed energy resources are generally small-scale resources installed close to energy consumption sites and include various technologies (IAE). Signals are emerging worldwide of distributed cheap(er) renewable energy sources, from solar microgrids providing electricity to remote Indonesian islands or women’s enterprises in India, to micro-turbines in Singapore that harvest power from light breezes.
data.impact_description: The rapid expansion of distributed energy sources are transforming not only the way electricity is generated, but also how it is traded, delivered and consumed.

data.headline: Growing number of countries in debt distress
data.description: A serious debt crisis is unfolding across developing economies, and the likelihood of a worsening outlook is high. More than 50 of the poorest developing countries are in danger of defaulting on their debt and becoming effectively bankrupt, including 28 of the world’s top 50 most climate-vulnerable countries.
data.impact_description: Despite several debt relief initiatives adopted since the start of the pandemic, the response to date has been insufficient. While countries most at risk (54 in total) represent just 3% of the global economy, they account for close to 18% of the global population and more than 50% of all people living in extreme poverty. The largest geographical subgroup among the 54 is Sub-Saharan Africa with 24 countries followed by Latin America and the Caribbean with 10 countries. See here for additional info.

data.headline: Climate shocks - more intense, more frequent
data.description: Climate change widespread, rapid, and intensifying. It is already affecting many weather and climate extremes in every region across the globe, according to IPCC.
data.impact_description: This has led to widespread adverse impacts and related losses and damages to nature and people, with vulnerable communities who have historically contributed the least to current climate change are disproportionately affected.

data.headline: Increasingly digital lives
data.description: Online life is becoming more immersive and people are spending more time there.  The digital dimension to all aspects of life is growing more significant as technological improvements allow digital to be deployed for an increasingly broad range of applications in business, government, media, health, education and entertainment.
data.impact_description: The increasing digital dimension across all aspects of life brings myriad challenges (eg social cohesion, controlling one's data and identity, mental health, equity and fairness, cybercrime) as well as opportunities (eg more efficient business processes, more inclusive public services or education, telehealth, telebanking, digital twins, etc).

data.headline: Growing concern for privacy
data.description: As the amounts of data created and stored grow exponentially, concern is growing around privacy and how these data are used by governments or companies. Some technical solutions are emerging to protect privacy or give users control over their data and identity.
data.impact_description: The growing volumes of data give huge potential leverage to governments and companies to control individuals' lives (whether through political control/surveillance, or manipulation of users for commercial profit).  The impact is unclear; if technological solutions allowing users to own and control their data become popular, that could protect people's privacy and rights, but many people seem content to exchange their data for convenience and entertainment.

data.headline: Inequitable distribution of technology persists
data.description: Almost half the world’s population, 3.7 billion people, most of them women, and most in developing countries, are still offline.  The digital divide cuts them off from opportunities that could improve their lives.  Even when online, the benefits of digital and other technologies are unevenly distributed.
data.impact_description: Uneven distribution of technology enables inequalities to persist, including gender equality, and deprives women and other marginalised groups of opportunities to improve their lives.  It also impedes progress towards the SDGs more broadly as excluded people are unable to fulfil their potential to build healthy, prosperous societies.

data.headline: New alliances for the global commons
data.description: Some countries, companies and NGOs are forming new alliances designed to protect or conserve global or shared goods like water, oceans, natural resources.  This is something of a contrary trend to "the race for scarce resources".
data.impact_description: It could help reach the SDGs if powerful countries or big companies band together to protect natural resources, and measure the benefits in financial terms. It could encourage others to follow suit.  It could even encourage collaboration in other areas, helping multilateral cooperation.

data.headline: Growing demand for new forms of governance
data.description: Traditional forms of governance are not necessarily adequate to cope with emerging technologies or changing values, like digital discourse, the metaverse, ESG investing or solar geoengineering.  New types of governance (like decentralised autonomous organizations (DAOs) or blockchain), or using familiar governance models in new ways, are needed for effective regulation.
data.impact_description: Some new types of governance like decentralised autonomous organizations may possibly allow a more democratic form of control.  In other novel areas (eg metaverse or geoengineering), the challenge of governance could be so difficult that no real solution is found, and these areas continue to be poorly governed and regulated.

data.headline: Increasing polarization
data.description:
Polarization is on the rise, creating more fractured, divided societies.  The 2023 Edelman Trust Barometer survey shows 21 of the 28 countries covered are either moderately or severely polarized.
https://www.edelman.com/trust/2023/trust-barometer
Polarization is exacerbated by social media encouraging people to stay in their own "echo chambers" of the like-minded.
data.impact_description: The increasing distrust in institutions and segments of society will lead to divided societies, which further undermines social cohesion. It is hard to govern in divided societies and even harder to rally societal support for important development objectives and related policies.

data.headline: Democratic backsliding
data.description: Global democracy, already under increasing threat over the last few years sees stagnation or further decline. The number of backsliding countries remains at its peak, and the number of countries moving towards authoritarianism is more than double the number moving towards democracy. As of the end 2021, nearly one half of the 173 countries assessed by International IDEA are experiencing declines in at least one subattribute of democracy.
data.impact_description: The reduction in accountability to people puts even more pressure the social contract in a world where many people think that elected leaders don't represent them. As social contracts become under pressure protests, social unrest and conflict can rise. Different forms of control or coercion restrict freedoms increasing the marginalization of certain groups further, as well as the potential of extremism. Development cooperation providers are faced with a dilemma, which is balancing their role in supporting governmental institutions, while respecting the principles of effective governance for sustainable development.

data.headline: Shifting nature of work
data.description: An interconnected tangle of technological disruption, economic forces, changing social structures and shifting values are restructuring the nature of work and the subsequent structure and stability of labour markets. A greater number of people are in precarious work, working multiple temporary jobs, or in grey or black-market employment. Tech innovations and value shifts wrought by the pandemic have enabled much more remote and hybrid working.
data.impact_description: Instability around work is adding fuel to populist movements, driving the resurgence of unions in some economies, and fueling structural economic instability.  The impact of more remote working and the opportunities of tech for greater productivity are still not fully clear.

data.headline: Mental health under stress
data.description: Global indicators of mental health have been trending negative for much of the decade, and continue to decline due to external shocks, from COVID to the Ukraine conflict to precarity in work, technology overload and more.
data.impact_description: Widespread declines in mental health are putting increased burden on social and health care systems and driving up mortality rates.  If the decline persists, worsening mental health in the longer term will damage productivity and impede progress towards prosperity.

data.headline: Growing inequalities
data.description:
Global prosperity has risen over the last few decades but the gap between the wealthy and the poor is growing. While in the west the middle class is shrinking, in Asia and Africa it is growing. By 2030, two-thirds of the middle-class population will live in Asia. 
COVID-19 has exacerbated poverty levels and inequality, with women, the poor, elderly, minorities, disabled and migrant populations, hit hardest and recovering more slowly. Climate change hits some groups and countries much worse than others.
Income inequality between countries has improved, yet income inequality within countries has become worse.  71 percent of the world’s population live in countries where inequality has grown.
data.impact_description: Growing inequalities are creating social tensions and increasing the perception (at least in some countries) that society is divided into the "haves" and "have-nots".  That could exacerbate polarization and social fractures.  It may also lead to greater pressure on governments to introduce policies that address inequality.

data.headline: Social contracts under pressure
data.description: The disconnect between people and institutions is growing, with many people no longer confident that the system works for them. Trust is declining, especially in government leaders. The question of what constitutes the social contract is becoming increasingly divisive and controversial.
data.impact_description: Governing is getting harder as the governance sphere becomes more complex and interdependent, and governments’ power, including fiscal space, constrained. As trust continues to decline globally and pockets of social unrest and the potential for more continue to grow.

The digital divide cuts them off from opportunities that could improve their lives.  Even when online, the benefits of digital and other technologies are unevenly distributed.
data.impact_description: Uneven distribution of technology enables inequalities to persist, including gender equality, and deprives women and other marginalised groups of opportunities to improve their lives.  It also impedes progress towards the SDGs more broadly as excluded people are unable to fulfil their potential to build healthy, prosperous societies.

data.headline: New alliances for the global commons
data.description: Some countries, companies and NGOs are forming new alliances designed to protect or conserve global or shared goods like water, oceans, natural resources.  This is something of a contrary trend to "the race for scarce resources".
data.impact_description: It could help reach the SDGs if powerful countries or big companies band together to protect natural resources, and measure the benefits in financial terms. It could encourage others to follow suit.  It could even encourage collaboration in other areas, helping multilateral cooperation.

data.headline: Growing demand for new forms of governance
data.description: Traditional forms of governance are not necessarily adequate to cope with emerging technologies or changing values, like digital discourse, the metaverse, ESG investing or solar geoengineering.  New types of governance (like decentralised autonomous organizations (DAOs) or blockchain), or using familiar governance models in new ways, are needed for effective regulation.
data.impact_description: Some new types of governance like decentralised autonomous organizations may possibly allow a more democratic form of control.  In other novel areas (eg metaverse or geoengineering), the challenge of governance could be so difficult that no real solution is found, and these areas continue to be poorly governed and regulated.

data.headline: Increasing polarization
data.description:
Polarization is on the rise, creating more fractured, divided societies.  The 2023 Edelman Trust Barometer survey shows 21 of the 28 countries covered are either moderately or severely polarized.
https://www.edelman.com/trust/2023/trust-barometer
Polarization is exacerbated by social media encouraging people to stay in their own "echo chambers" of the like-minded.
data.impact_description: The increasing distrust in institutions and segments of society will lead to divided societies, which further undermines social cohesion. It is hard to govern in divided societies and even harder to rally societal support for important development objectives and related policies.

data.headline: Democratic backsliding
data.description: Global democracy, already under increasing threat over the last few years sees stagnation or further decline. The number of backsliding countries remains at its peak, and the number of countries moving towards authoritarianism is more than double the number moving towards democracy. As of the end 2021, nearly one half of the 173 countries assessed by International IDEA are experiencing declines in at least one subattribute of democracy.
data.impact_description: The reduction in accountability to people puts even more pressure the social contract in a world where many people think that elected leaders don't represent them. As social contracts become under pressure protests, social unrest and conflict can rise. Different forms of control or coercion restrict freedoms increasing the marginalization of certain groups further, as well as the potential of extremism. Development cooperation providers are faced with a dilemma, which is balancing their role in supporting governmental institutions, while respecting the principles of effective governance for sustainable development.

data.headline: Shifting nature of work
data.description: An interconnected tangle of technological disruption, economic forces, changing social structures and shifting values are restructuring the nature of work and the subsequent structure and stability of labour markets. A greater number of people are in precarious work, working multiple temporary jobs, or in grey or black-market employment. Tech innovations and value shifts wrought by the pandemic have enabled much more remote and hybrid working.
data.impact_description: Instability around work is adding fuel to populist movements, driving the resurgence of unions in some economies, and fueling structural economic instability.  The impact of more remote working and the opportunities of tech for greater productivity are still not fully clear.

data.headline: Mental health under stress
data.description: Global indicators of mental health have been trending negative for much of the decade, and continue to decline due to external shocks, from COVID to the Ukraine conflict to precarity in work, technology overload and more.
data.impact_description: Widespread declines in mental health are putting increased burden on social and health care systems and driving up mortality rates.  If the decline persists, worsening mental health in the longer term will damage productivity and impede progress towards prosperity.

data.headline: Growing inequalities
data.description:
Global prosperity has risen over the last few decades but the gap between the wealthy and the poor is growing. While in the west the middle class is shrinking, in Asia and Africa it is growing. By 2030, two-thirds of the middle-class population will live in Asia. 
COVID-19 has exacerbated poverty levels and inequality, with women, the poor, elderly, minorities, disabled and migrant populations, hit hardest and recovering more slowly. Climate change hits some groups and countries much worse than others.
Income inequality between countries has improved, yet income inequality within countries has become worse.  71 percent of the world’s population live in countries where inequality has grown.
data.impact_description: Growing inequalities are creating social tensions and increasing the perception (at least in some countries) that society is divided into the "haves" and "have-nots".  That could exacerbate polarization and social fractures.  It may also lead to greater pressure on governments to introduce policies that address inequality.

data.headline: Social contracts under pressure
data.description: The disconnect between people and institutions is growing, with many people no longer confident that the system works for them. Trust is declining, especially in government leaders. The question of what constitutes the social contract is becoming increasingly divisive and controversial.
data.impact_description: Governing is getting harder as the governance sphere becomes more complex and interdependent, and governments’ power, including fiscal space, constrained. As trust continues to decline globally and pockets of social unrest and the potential for more continue to grow.

data.headline: More tech innovations for philanthropy
data.description: The philanthropic sector is expanding into new ways of giving, like tech innovations (blockchain-powered donations, charity prediction markets) and new currencies (crypto, NFTs).  Some billionaire philanthropists are dedicating their fortunes to development goals, some through new philosophies like effective altruism.
data.impact_description: The impact to date is fairly small as even large philanthropic donations are dwarfed by ODA (even though some donors are cutting ODA) and new technologies/ways of giving like crypto are in their infancy (and might anyway just replace donations that would have been made through traditional means).  In the longer term, it's possible that these mechanisms, and philosophies behind giving like effective altruism, might either convince more people to give, and/or actually increase the impact of their giving (because donations are channelled to goals with greater impact).

data.headline: Climate activism expanding
data.description: In recent years, climate activism has increased with millions of people around the world taking to the streets to demand urgent action on climate change. Climate change is also increasingly becoming a focus of legal action, with individuals, organizations, and governments using the law to hold companies and governments accountable for their role in causing and exacerbating climate change.
data.impact_description: Legal action can drive change in the behaviour and practices of corporations and governments and the implementation of stronger climate policies. However, legal action is not a silver bullet, and it must be combined with broader collective action to achieve the transformative change needed to address the climate crisis.

data.headline: Increased use of weather modifying technology
data.description: There is growing interest and investment in weather modifying technology, which involves the deliberate manipulation of weather patterns to mitigate the impacts of climate change, droughts, and other weather-related hazards. These technologies range from cloud seeding and hail suppression to more complex geoengineering solutions, such as solar radiation management and carbon capture.
data.impact_description: Unilateral use of these technologies raises significant ethical, social, and environmental concerns. Weather modifying technology could have unintended consequences and risks, and may be used to further geopolitical interests or exacerbate existing inequalities.

data.headline: Boom in breakthrough technology
data.description: We are currently experiencing a boom in breakthrough technologies, with advances in fields such as green technologies, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, nanotechnology, and quantum computing.
data.impact_description: These technologies have the potential to revolutionize industries, solve some of our most pressing global challenges, and create new economic opportunities. However, they also pose significant ethical, social, and economic challenges, which require careful consideration and proactive measures to address.

data.headline: Ever-stronger AI
data.description: Advancements in AI will disrupt every industry within the next decade, and Future Today Institute classifies it as a general-purpose technology. Like the steam engine and the internet before it, AI has the potential to influence entire economies and to alter society through political, economic, and social structures.
data.impact_description: Exponential advances in digital technology are increasing the gap between the haves and the have-nots, those who aren’t shaping our digital world, or aren’t even able to participate in or benefit from it. In such a rapidly-changing field, policy and regulation for the public interest is vital, particularly in areas in which the consequences of such rapid advances are largely unknown.

data.headline: Distributed energy solutions proliferate
data.description: Distributed energy resources are generally small-scale resources installed close to energy consumption sites and include various technologies (IAE). Signals are emerging worldwide of distributed cheap(er) renewable energy sources, from solar microgrids providing electricity to remote Indonesian islands or women’s enterprises in India, to micro-turbines in Singapore that harvest power from light breezes.
data.impact_description: The rapid expansion of distributed energy sources are transforming not only the way electricity is generated, but also how it is traded, delivered and consumed.

data.headline: Growing number of countries in debt distress
data.description: A serious debt crisis is unfolding across developing economies, and the likelihood of a worsening outlook is high. More than 50 of the poorest developing countries are in danger of defaulting on their debt and becoming effectively bankrupt, including 28 of the world’s top 50 most climate-vulnerable countries.
data.impact_description: Despite several debt relief initiatives adopted since the start of the pandemic, the response to date has been insufficient. While countries most at risk (54 in total) represent just 3% of the global economy, they account for close to 18% of the global population and more than 50% of all people living in extreme poverty. The largest geographical subgroup among the 54 is Sub-Saharan Africa with 24 countries followed by Latin America and the Caribbean with 10 countries. See here for additional info.

data.headline: Climate shocks - more intense, more frequent
data.description: Climate change widespread, rapid, and intensifying. It is already affecting many weather and climate extremes in every region across the globe, according to IPCC.
data.impact_description: This has led to widespread adverse impacts and related losses and damages to nature and people, with vulnerable communities who have historically contributed the least to current climate change are disproportionately affected.

data.headline: Increasingly digital lives
data.description: Online life is becoming more immersive and people are spending more time there.  The digital dimension to all aspects of life is growing more significant as technological improvements allow digital to be deployed for an increasingly broad range of applications in business, government, media, health, education and entertainment.
data.impact_description: The increasing digital dimension across all aspects of life brings myriad challenges (eg social cohesion, controlling one's data and identity, mental health, equity and fairness, cybercrime) as well as opportunities (eg more efficient business processes, more inclusive public services or education, telehealth, telebanking, digital twins, etc).

data.headline: Growing concern for privacy
data.description: As the amounts of data created and stored grow exponentially, concern is growing around privacy and how these data are used by governments or companies. Some technical solutions are emerging to protect privacy or give users control over their data and identity.
data.impact_description: The growing volumes of data give huge potential leverage to governments and companies to control individuals' lives (whether through political control/surveillance, or manipulation of users for commercial profit).  The impact is unclear; if technological solutions allowing users to own and control their data become popular, that could protect people's privacy and rights, but many people seem content to exchange their data for convenience and entertainment.

data.impact_description: The impact to date is fairly small as even large philanthropic donations are dwarfed by ODA (even though some donors are cutting ODA) and new technologies/ways of giving like crypto are in their infancy (and might anyway just replace donations that would have been made through traditional means).  In the longer term, it's possible that these mechanisms, and philosophies behind giving like effective altruism, might either convince more people to give, and/or actually increase the impact of their giving (because donations are channelled to goals with greater impact).

data.headline: Climate activism expanding
data.description: In recent years, climate activism has increased with millions of people around the world taking to the streets to demand urgent action on climate change. Climate change is also increasingly becoming a focus of legal action, with individuals, organizations, and governments using the law to hold companies and governments accountable for their role in causing and exacerbating climate change.
data.impact_description: Legal action can drive change in the behaviour and practices of corporations and governments and the implementation of stronger climate policies. However, legal action is not a silver bullet, and it must be combined with broader collective action to achieve the transformative change needed to address the climate crisis.

data.headline: Increased use of weather modifying technology
data.description: There is growing interest and investment in weather modifying technology, which involves the deliberate manipulation of weather patterns to mitigate the impacts of climate change, droughts, and other weather-related hazards. These technologies range from cloud seeding and hail suppression to more complex geoengineering solutions, such as solar radiation management and carbon capture.
data.impact_description: Unilateral use of these technologies raises significant ethical, social, and environmental concerns. Weather modifying technology could have unintended consequences and risks, and may be used to further geopolitical interests or exacerbate existing inequalities.

data.headline: Boom in breakthrough technology
data.description: We are currently experiencing a boom in breakthrough technologies, with advances in fields such as green technologies, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, nanotechnology, and quantum computing.
data.impact_description: These technologies have the potential to revolutionize industries, solve some of our most pressing global challenges, and create new economic opportunities. However, they also pose significant ethical, social, and economic challenges, which require careful consideration and proactive measures to address.

data.headline: Ever-stronger AI
data.description: Advancements in AI will disrupt every industry within the next decade, and Future Today Institute classifies it as a general-purpose technology. Like the steam engine and the internet before it, AI has the potential to influence entire economies and to alter society through political, economic, and social structures.
data.impact_description: Exponential advances in digital technology are increasing the gap between the haves and the have-nots, those who aren’t shaping our digital world, or aren’t even able to participate in or benefit from it. In such a rapidly-changing field, policy and regulation for the public interest is vital, particularly in areas in which the consequences of such rapid advances are largely unknown.

data.headline: Distributed energy solutions proliferate
data.description: Distributed energy resources are generally small-scale resources installed close to energy consumption sites and include various technologies (IAE). Signals are emerging worldwide of distributed cheap(er) renewable energy sources, from solar microgrids providing electricity to remote Indonesian islands or women’s enterprises in India, to micro-turbines in Singapore that harvest power from light breezes.
data.impact_description: The rapid expansion of distributed energy sources are transforming not only the way electricity is generated, but also how it is traded, delivered and consumed.

data.headline: Growing number of countries in debt distress
data.description: A serious debt crisis is unfolding across developing economies, and the likelihood of a worsening outlook is high. More than 50 of the poorest developing countries are in danger of defaulting on their debt and becoming effectively bankrupt, including 28 of the world’s top 50 most climate-vulnerable countries.
data.impact_description: Despite several debt relief initiatives adopted since the start of the pandemic, the response to date has been insufficient. While countries most at risk (54 in total) represent just 3% of the global economy, they account for close to 18% of the global population and more than 50% of all people living in extreme poverty. The largest geographical subgroup among the 54 is Sub-Saharan Africa with 24 countries followed by Latin America and the Caribbean with 10 countries. See here for additional info.

data.headline: Climate shocks - more intense, more frequent
data.description: Climate change widespread, rapid, and intensifying. It is already affecting many weather and climate extremes in every region across the globe, according to IPCC.
data.impact_description: This has led to widespread adverse impacts and related losses and damages to nature and people, with vulnerable communities who have historically contributed the least to current climate change are disproportionately affected.

data.headline: Increasingly digital lives
data.description: Online life is becoming more immersive and people are spending more time there.  The digital dimension to all aspects of life is growing more significant as technological improvements allow digital to be deployed for an increasingly broad range of applications in business, government, media, health, education and entertainment.
data.impact_description: The increasing digital dimension across all aspects of life brings myriad challenges (eg social cohesion, controlling one's data and identity, mental health, equity and fairness, cybercrime) as well as opportunities (eg more efficient business processes, more inclusive public services or education, telehealth, telebanking, digital twins, etc).

data.headline: Growing concern for privacy
data.description: As the amounts of data created and stored grow exponentially, concern is growing around privacy and how these data are used by governments or companies. Some technical solutions are emerging to protect privacy or give users control over their data and identity.
data.impact_description: The growing volumes of data give huge potential leverage to governments and companies to control individuals' lives (whether through political control/surveillance, or manipulation of users for commercial profit).  The impact is unclear; if technological solutions allowing users to own and control their data become popular, that could protect people's privacy and rights, but many people seem content to exchange their data for convenience and entertainment.

data.headline: Inequitable distribution of technology persists
data.description: Almost half the world’s population, 3.7 billion people, most of them women, and most in developing countries, are still offline.  The digital divide cuts them off from opportunities that could improve their lives.  Even when online, the benefits of digital and other technologies are unevenly distributed.
data.impact_description: Uneven distribution of technology enables inequalities to persist, including gender equality, and deprives women and other marginalised groups of opportunities to improve their lives.  It also impedes progress towards the SDGs more broadly as excluded people are unable to fulfil their potential to build healthy, prosperous societies.

data.headline: New alliances for the global commons
data.description: Some countries, companies and NGOs are forming new alliances designed to protect or conserve global or shared goods like water, oceans, natural resources.  This is something of a contrary trend to "the race for scarce resources".
data.impact_description: It could help reach the SDGs if powerful countries or big companies band together to protect natural resources, and measure the benefits in financial terms. It could encourage others to follow suit.  It could even encourage collaboration in other areas, helping multilateral cooperation.

data.headline: Growing demand for new forms of governance
data.description: Traditional forms of governance are not necessarily adequate to cope with emerging technologies or changing values, like digital discourse, the metaverse, ESG investing or solar geoengineering.  New types of governance (like decentralised autonomous organizations (DAOs) or blockchain), or using familiar governance models in new ways, are needed for effective regulation.
data.impact_description: Some new types of governance like decentralised autonomous organizations may possibly allow a more democratic form of control.  In other novel areas (eg metaverse or geoengineering), the challenge of governance could be so difficult that no real solution is found, and these areas continue to be poorly governed and regulated.

data.headline: Increasing polarization
data.description:
Polarization is on the rise, creating more fractured, divided societies.  The 2023 Edelman Trust Barometer survey shows 21 of the 28 countries covered are either moderately or severely polarized.
https://www.edelman.com/trust/2023/trust-barometer
Polarization is exacerbated by social media encouraging people to stay in their own "echo chambers" of the like-minded.
data.impact_description: The increasing distrust in institutions and segments of society will lead to divided societies, which further undermines social cohesion. It is hard to govern in divided societies and even harder to rally societal support for important development objectives and related policies.

data.headline: Democratic backsliding
data.description: Global democracy, already under increasing threat over the last few years sees stagnation or further decline. The number of backsliding countries remains at its peak, and the number of countries moving towards authoritarianism is more than double the number moving towards democracy. As of the end 2021, nearly one half of the 173 countries assessed by International IDEA are experiencing declines in at least one subattribute of democracy.
data.impact_description: The reduction in accountability to people puts even more pressure the social contract in a world where many people think that elected leaders don't represent them. As social contracts become under pressure protests, social unrest and conflict can rise. Different forms of control or coercion restrict freedoms increasing the marginalization of certain groups further, as well as the potential of extremism. Development cooperation providers are faced with a dilemma, which is balancing their role in supporting governmental institutions, while respecting the principles of effective governance for sustainable development.

data.headline: Shifting nature of work
data.description: An interconnected tangle of technological disruption, economic forces, changing social structures and shifting values are restructuring the nature of work and the subsequent structure and stability of labour markets. A greater number of people are in precarious work, working multiple temporary jobs, or in grey or black-market employment. Tech innovations and value shifts wrought by the pandemic have enabled much more remote and hybrid working.
data.impact_description: Instability around work is adding fuel to populist movements, driving the resurgence of unions in some economies, and fueling structural economic instability.  The impact of more remote working and the opportunities of tech for greater productivity are still not fully clear.

data.headline: Mental health under stress
data.description: Global indicators of mental health have been trending negative for much of the decade, and continue to decline due to external shocks, from COVID to the Ukraine conflict to precarity in work, technology overload and more.
data.impact_description: Widespread declines in mental health are putting increased burden on social and health care systems and driving up mortality rates.  If the decline persists, worsening mental health in the longer term will damage productivity and impede progress towards prosperity.

data.headline: Growing inequalities
data.description:
Global prosperity has risen over the last few decades but the gap between the wealthy and the poor is growing. While in the west the middle class is shrinking, in Asia and Africa it is growing. By 2030, two-thirds of the middle-class population will live in Asia. 
COVID-19 has exacerbated poverty levels and inequality, with women, the poor, elderly, minorities, disabled and migrant populations, hit hardest and recovering more slowly. Climate change hits some groups and countries much worse than others.
Income inequality between countries has improved, yet income inequality within countries has become worse.  71 percent of the world’s population live in countries where inequality has grown.
data.impact_description: Growing inequalities are creating social tensions and increasing the perception (at least in some countries) that society is divided into the "haves" and "have-nots".  That could exacerbate polarization and social fractures.  It may also lead to greater pressure on governments to introduce policies that address inequality.

data.headline: Social contracts under pressure
data.description: The disconnect between people and institutions is growing, with many people no longer confident that the system works for them. Trust is declining, especially in government leaders. The question of what constitutes the social contract is becoming increasingly divisive and controversial.
data.impact_description: Governing is getting harder as the governance sphere becomes more complex and interdependent, and governments’ power, including fiscal space, constrained. As trust continues to decline globally and pockets of social unrest and the potential for more continue to grow.
